questions.text: Concerned parents of a 7-year-old boy bringtheir child to the pediatrician for evaluation.They note that ever since he was an infant, their son has never wanted to be held, cries whenever he is bathed, and becomes veryupset when his daily routine is changed in any way. Although the child cannot yet read, hisparents remark that he can identify the state oforigin of any car license plate and almostexclusively plays with replicas of car license plates. The child’s speaks in complete sentencesand has a good vocabulary, but hisbehavior seems odd and he does not make eyecontact when spoken to. Medical evaluation is unremarkable. As an adolescent, this boy is likely to have the most difficulty in which of the following areas?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Making friends. This 7-year-old boy exhibits behavior that is highly suggestive of autism spectrum disorder (ASD), particularly given his lack of social interest (e.g., not wanting to be held, difficulty with eye contact), rigid routines (e.g., distress when routines are changed), and focused, repetitive interests (e.g., obsession with car license plates). One of the hallmark features of ASD is social communication deficits, which often lead to difficulty forming and maintaining friendships. As the child grows into adolescence, his challenges with social reciprocity, interpreting social cues, and engaging in typical peer interactions will likely make friendship-building the most difficult area for him. Explanation of Incorrect Options: (A) Paying attention in school – Incorrect While children with ASD may have challenges with attention due to difficulties in shifting focus or engaging in tasks of interest, the problem described here is more social in nature rather than related to general attention in academic settings. Additionally, the boy’s ability to speak in complete sentences and have a good vocabulary suggests he might have adequate cognitive functioning to manage attention tasks. (B) Concentrating on relevant stimuli – Incorrect Children with ASD often have trouble with sensory processing and can become fixated on specific stimuli (as seen with the boy's interest in license plates). However, the primary issue described here is social interaction difficulties, not a general problem with focusing on stimuli. Therefore, while concentration issues may arise, they are not the most pressing concern in this case. (C) Caring for pets – Incorrect Although children with ASD may struggle with empathy or reciprocal care in relationships (including with pets), there is no direct indication from the scenario that this boy has difficulties with caring for pets. The focus in this case is on his social difficulties and behavioral rigidity, rather than his ability to care for others or animals.

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl who had been developing typically since birth begins to withdraw socially and then stops speaking altogether. Also, instead of purposeful hand movements, the child has begun to show repetitivehand wringing behavior. The chromosome most likely to be involved in this disorder is chromosome
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) X. The symptoms described in the scenario are most consistent with Rett syndrome, a neurodevelopmental disorder that primarily affects females. Rett syndrome typically presents with normal early development followed by a period of regression, often between 6 to 18 months of age. This regression includes a loss of purposeful hand movements, social withdrawal, loss of speech, and the development of stereotypical hand movements such as hand wringing. Rett syndrome is caused by mutations in the MECP2 gene located on the X chromosome, which is why the most likely chromosome involved in this disorder is the X chromosome. Explanation of Incorrect Options: (A) 21 – Incorrect Chromosome 21 is associated with Down syndrome, a condition caused by trisomy of chromosome 21. Down syndrome is characterized by intellectual disability, physical growth delays, and certain characteristic facial features. While developmental delays are a feature of Down syndrome, the specific symptoms described in this question (social withdrawal, cessation of speech, and hand wringing) are not typical of Down syndrome. (B) 16 – Incorrect Chromosome 16 is associated with various genetic disorders, but it is not the chromosome involved in Rett syndrome. Some disorders related to chromosome 16 may include various types of epileptic syndromes and autosomal dominant inheritance patterns, but Rett syndrome is not linked to this chromosome. (C) 18 – Incorrect Chromosome 18 is associated with conditions like Edwards syndrome (trisomy 18), which causes severe developmental and physical abnormalities, often leading to death in infancy or early childhood. While these children may exhibit developmental delays, the specific regression of speech and hand movements described in Rett syndrome is not characteristic of Edwards syndrome.

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl who has been in foster care since birth is very friendly and affectionatewith strangers. She puts her arms outto them to be picked up and then “cuddles up” to them. The foster mother states thatthe child has “behavior problems” and thennotes that she has never felt “close” to thechild. The most likely explanation for this child’s behavior toward strangers is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Reactive attachment disorder, disinhibited type. Reactive attachment disorder (RAD) is a condition that can occur in young children who have experienced extreme neglect or a lack of stable attachment figures, such as children who have been in foster care or orphanages. RAD can present in two types: Inhibited type: Children are emotionally withdrawn and do not seek comfort or show an interest in social interactions. Disinhibited type: Children display indiscriminate friendliness, being overly affectionate and engaging with strangers in an inappropriate or overly familiar manner. The behavior described in this case — the child being overly friendly and affectionate with strangers, seeking out physical closeness with them — is characteristic of disinhibited RAD. This behavior reflects a lack of appropriate attachment to caregivers and the absence of selective bonding, which are hallmark features of the disorder. Explanation of Incorrect Options: (A) Autism – Incorrect While children with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) may exhibit difficulties with social interaction and communication, the behavior described (excessive friendliness and affection toward strangers) is not characteristic of autism. In fact, children with ASD may show social withdrawal or difficulty with social cues, which is different from the indiscriminate friendliness seen in RAD (disinhibited type). Additionally, autism typically involves restricted or repetitive behaviors, which are not described in this case. (B) Rett’s disorder – Incorrect Rett’s disorder is a neurodevelopmental disorder that typically affects females and is characterized by a period of normal development followed by a regression in motor and social skills. Symptoms include loss of purposeful hand movements, impaired speech, and stereotyped hand wringing. This diagnosis does not align with the description of the child’s behavior in this case, which is more focused on social interactions with strangers rather than the developmental regression typical of Rett’s disorder. (C) Reactive attachment disorder, inhibited type – Incorrect In the inhibited type of RAD, children tend to be withdrawn and do not seek comfort or respond to social interactions. They may avoid emotional connections with others. However, the behavior described in the case — the child’s affection toward strangers and desire to be picked up — is not consistent with the inhibited type, but rather with the disinhibited type, where children show excessive social behavior and indiscriminate attachment to others.

questions.text: Features of AUTISM SPECTRUM DISORDER are all except? (PGI MAY 19)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Responds well to pharmacotherapy Autism spectrum disorder is known for developmental delay and presence of restrictive, repetitive and stereotyped behaviour. And there is strong family history also but it doesn’t responds much to pharmacotherapy

questions.text: A 3 y old child, has undergone sexual abuse in the past. Which of the following factors is the least to influence in, the child developing depressive disorder in future? (JIPMER MAY 19)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Abuse was penetrative ? With respect to rape, it need not to be penetrative for a victim to develop psychological trauma. ? Others are true, i.e., those with family or past history of depression; young age; poor cognitive function Risk factors for future depression in child sexual abuse are • Maternal depression and abuse have independent effects on depression, and the combination may be associated with higher levels of depression in children. ? Child with low self esteem ? Difficulty relating to peers

questions.text: Savant syndrome is most commonly associated with?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Autism Savant syndrome is a rare, but extraordinary, condition in which persons with serious mental disabilities, including autistic disorder, have some ‘island of genius’ which stands in marked, incongruous contrast to overall handicap. As many as one in 10 persons with autistic disorder have such remarkable abilities in varying degrees, although savant syndrome occurs in other developmental disabilities or in other types of central nervous system injury or disease as well

questions.text: SEQUENTIAL ARRANGEMENT (AIIMS NEW PATTERN) Arrange the following symptoms of ADHD in order of their response to treatment (from earliest to last… 1. Acts before thinking, on the spur of the moment 2. Talks excessively 3. Doesn’t seem to listen
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 2, 1, 3 (Ref : Niraj Ahuja) ADHD SYMPTOMS, response to treatment is in following order: 1. Hyperactivity i. Fidgety. ii. Difficulty in sitting still at one place for long. iii. Moving about here and there. iv. Talks excessively. v. Interference in other people’s activities. 2. Impulsivity i. Acts before thinking, on the spur of the moment. ii. Difficulty in waiting for turn at work or play 3. Attention deficit i. Fails to finish the things started. ii. Shifts from one uncompleted activity to another. iii. Doesn’t seem to listen. iv. Easily distracted by external stimuli. v. Often loses things.

choices.text: If a, b, c are correct
If a and c are correct
If b and d are correct
If all four (a, b, c, & d) are correct

questions.text: Clinical features of tourette’s syndrome? a. Grunting b. Excessive eye blinking c. Palilalia d. Echolalia
questions.solution: Correct Answer ( A) TOURETTE’S SYNDROME 1. Motor tics (Eye blinking) 2. Vocal tics (throat clearing, grunting 3. Coprolalia (obscene words) 4. Palilalia (repeating words)

questions.text: A 3 year old girl child presents to the OPD with complaints of loss of purposeful movements and involuntary movements. Also with decrease in head circumference (microcephaly) and hand wringing movements. What is your most probable diagnosis? (***)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Rett syndrome

questions.text: Children with conduct disorders in childhood later on develop which personality disorder in adulthood? (***)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Antisocial PD Conduct disorder adolescents are more prone to develop antisocial personality in adulthood

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy was seen by a school counsellor after the teachers complained of his behaviour in school. He frequently becomes angry towards others and loses his temper in class. His parents report that at home, he refuses to comply with house rules, often stays up later than he is supposed to, and frequently talks back to them. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Oppositional defiant disorder Children with oppositional defiant disorder usually have problems with authority figures such as parents and teachers. Unlike children with conduct disorder, they do not break rules of society and do not commit crimes

choices.text: Mild mental retarded can reach up to sixth grade level of education
Moderate mental retarded can reach up to second grade level of education
Severe mentally retarded needs continuous care and supervision
DSM-5 stresses on adaptive functioning as a measure of grading severity of intellectual disability.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true with respect to “level of functioning” in intellectual disability children?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Severe mentally retarded needs continuous care and supervision

questions.text: A 4 year and eleven month old boy is all the time so restless that the rest of the class is unable to concentrate. He is hardly ever in his seat but roams around the hall. He has difficulty playing quietly. The most likely diagnosis is -
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) ADHD Hyperactivity and difficulty concentration point towards diagnosis of ADHD

questions.text: A 3 year old child developmental with delayed speech, and difficulty in communication, concentration, not making friends
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Autism Delayed milestones(speech), impairment in communication and social interaction seen in ADHA

questions.text: A two years old girl child is brought to the outpatient with features of hand wringing stereotype movements, impaired language and communication development, breath holding spells, poor social skills and deceleration of head growth after six months of age. The most likely diagnosis is -
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Rett’s syndrome Regression of milestones (deceleration of head growth) after normal development till 6 months is highly suggestive of ASD.

questions.text: A 14 year old boy has difficulty in expressing himself in writing and makes frequent spelling mistakes, does not follow instruction and cannot wait for his turn while playing a game. He is likely to be suffering from
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Specific learning disability Writing difficulties and spelling mistakes point towards diagnosis of Specific learning disability

choices.text: Leave his as normal adolescent problem
Rule out an oppositional defiant disorder

questions.text: An 8 year old student complains of lack of interest in studies for last 6 months. He has frequent quarrels with his parents and has frequent headaches. The most appropriate clinical approach would be
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Rule out depression Somatic complaints(headache), quarrelsome with parents(anger outbursts and irritability) and lack of interest in studies may be alarming signs of depression in children

questions.text: 12 year old girl has a history of 1 year of constant grammatical mistakes and spelling errors. But her performance in other subjects is average, she performs good in oral assesment and there is no difficulty in reading. Most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) SLD (Latest exam Q) · A diagnosis of disorder of written expression is based on a child's poor performance on composing written text, including handwriting and impaired ability to spell and to place words sequentially in coherent sentences, compared with most other children of the same age and intellectual ability. In addition to spelling mistakes, a child with writing disorder may have serious grammatical mistakes, such as using incorrect tenses, forgetting words in sentences, and placing words in the wrong order. Punctuation may be incorrect, and the child may have poor ability to remember which words begin with capital letters. Poor handwriting may also contribute to writing disorder, including letters that are not legible, inverted letters, and mixtures of capital and lowercase letters in a given word. · Children with disorder of written expression have difficulties early in grade school in spelling words and expressing their thoughts according to age-appropriate grammatical norms. Their spoken and written sentences contain an unusually large number of grammatical errors and poor paragraph organization. During and after the second grade, these children commonly make simple grammatical errors in writing a short sentence. For example, despite constant reminders, they frequently fail to capitalize the first letter of the first word in a sentence and to end the sentence with a period. Common features of the disorder of written expression are spelling errors, grammatical errors, punctuation errors, poor paragraph organization, and poor handwriting. · As they grow older and progress into higher grades in school, such children's spoken and written sentences become more conspicuously primitive, odd, and inferior to what is expected of students at their grade level. Their word choices are erroneous and inappropriate; their paragraphs are disorganized and are not in proper sequence; and spelling correctly becomes increasingly difficult as their vocabulary becomes larger and more abstract. Associated features of disorder of written expression include refusal or reluctance to go to school and to do assigned written homework, poor academic performance in other areas (e.g., mathematics), general avoidance of school work, truancy, attention deficit, and conduct disturbance

questions.text: A 24-year old male patient presents with a 10-year history of repeated eye blinking and grunting. He complains that the symptoms have now increased in frequency so much that he does not have any control over them and they have started disturbing his routine activity and social life, making him depressed.The best medication that would benefit him is–
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Risperidone Tic disorders are distinguished by the type of tic symptoms, their frequency, and the pattern in which they emerge over time. Tics are abnormal movements or vocalizations that most commonly affect the muscles of the face and neck, such as eye-blinking, head-jerking, mouth-grimacing, or head-shaking. Typical vocal tics include throat-clearing, grunting, snorting, and coughing. Tics are defined as rapid and repetitive muscle contractions resulting in movements or vocalizations that are experienced as involuntary. Motor and vocal tics are divided into simple and complex types. Simple motor tics are those composed of repetitive, rapid contractions of functionally similar muscle groups for example, eye-blinking, neck-jerking, shoulder-shrugging, and facial-grimacing. Common simple vocal tics include coughing, throat-clearing, grunting, sniffing, snorting, and barking. Complex motor tics appear to be more purposeful and ritualistic than simple tics. Common complex motor tics include grooming behaviors, the smelling of objects, jumping, touching behaviors, echopraxia (imitation of observed behavior), and copropraxia (display of obscene gestures). Complex vocal tics include repeating words or phrases out of context, coprolalia (use of obscene words or phrases), palilalia (a person's repeating his or her words), and echolalia (repetition of the last-heard words of others). The treatment of chronic motor or vocal tic disorder depends on the severity and frequency of the tics; the patient's subjective distress; the effects of the tics on school or work, job performance, and socialization; and the presence of any other concomitant mental disorder. Psychotherapy may be indicated to minimize the secondary social difficulties caused by severe tics. Several studies found that behavioraltechniques, particularly habit reversal treatments, were effective in treating chronic motor or vocal tic disorder. “When severe, tics may be reduced through the use of atypical antipsychotics such as RISPERIDONE”. (Note: Tic being a hyperdopaminergic state, responds to D2 blockers, risperidone and haloperidol etc)

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl is brought to her pediatrician because her parents think she does not seem to be “developing normally.” The girl’s mother states that her daughter seemed normal for at least the first 2 to 3 years of her life. She was walking and beginning to speak in sentences. She was able to play with her mother and older sister. The mother has been noticing that over the past 2 months her daughter has lost these previously acquired abilities. She will no longer play with anyone else and has stopped speaking entirely. She has lost all bowel control, when previously she had not needed a diaper for at least a year. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Heller’s/Childhood disintegrative disorder Childhood disintegrative disorder is characterized by apparently normal development through at least the first 2 years of life. During this time, age-appropriate skills such as verbal and nonverbal communication, social relationships, bowel and bladder control, and play all develop normally. The disease manifests itself as a clinically significant loss of previously acquired skills before the age of 10. In Rett disorder, the onset of the disease occurs earlier, usually 6 months after birth, and there are characteristic hand stereotypies that do not occur in childhood disintegrative disorder. The presence of the apparently normal development of speech and other behaviors, followed by the loss of these, distinguishes this disorder from autism and Asperger disorder where there is no loss of previously acquired skills.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the psychiatrist because his mother says the boy is really unamanageable. She reports that he constantly argues with her and his father, does not follow any of the house rules, and always teases his sister. She says that he is vindictive and loses his temper easily. The mother notes that the boy started this behavior only about 1 year previously. While she states that this behavior started at home, it has now spread to school, where his grades are dropping because he refuses to participate. The patient maintains that none of this is his fault––his parents are simply being unreasonable. He denies feeling depressed and notes that he sleeps well through the night. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Oppositional Defiant Disorder The child is disruptive, unmanageable at home. Angry, irritable, vindictiveness are all features. But the child does not violate rights of others, nor that there is any evidence of physical abuse to parents (rules out conduct disorder)

questions.text: An adoloscent whose chronological age was 18y, mental age was corresponding to 12y; according to binet formula for I.Q. calculation, he should be (as per DSM grading)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Dull normal intelligence There is a catch here. You all know how to calculate I.Q. But answer is not 66.6 I.Q. (Mild) Pg 178 kaplan 10th states : (“Because it is impossible to measure age-associated changes in intellectual power after the age of 15 with available intelligence tests, the highest divisor in the IQ formula is 15”) So, for this case I.Q. is 12/15 * 100 = 80.

questions.text: SSRIs should be carefully used in the young for the management of depression due to increase in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Suicidal ideation SSRI use in children and adolescents is associated with “black box” warning, with an increased risk of suicidal ideation, especially with fluoxetine

choices.text: They may be very sensitive to specific sounds
They often prefer imaginative play with dolls
They often perform repetitive stereotyped behaviors

questions.text: Children with autism exhibit all of the following except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Autistic children usually prefer playing with objects like spinning plates or tops. Imaginative play with dolls requires a social sense, which is characteristically lacking in autism. Most autistic people have difficulty with new experiences, and may be very sensitive to specific sounds. They often perform repetitive, stereotyped motor acts. Some engage in self- injurious behaviors , including biting themselves of banging their heads

questions.text: Tourette’s syndrome is associated with all of the following except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Tourette’s is commonly associated with ADHD, OCD and Depression

questions.text: A 14- year-old boy has difficulty in expressing himself in writing and makes frequent spelling mistakes. He passes his examination with poor marks. However his mathematical ability and social adjustment are appropriate for his age. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Only spelling mistakes and writing mistakes with good social adjustment points towards diagnosis of specific learning disability

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl who has been in foster care since birth is very friendly and affectionate with strangers. She puts her arms out to them to be picked up and then cuddles up to them. The foster mother states that the child has behavior problems and then notes that she has never felt close to the child. The most likely explanation for this child’s behavior toward strangers is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The most likely diagnosis for this child is reactive attachment disorder,Disinhibited type. Children with this disorder form indiscriminate attachments toStrangers because their primary attachment figure, here the foster mother, does notInteract normally with the child. Autistic disorder, asperger’s disorder, and rett’s disorder are all characterized by decreased, not increased, social interaction

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl who had been developing typically since birth begins to withdraw socially and then stops speaking altogether. Also, instead of purposeful hand movements, the child has begun to show repetitive hand wringing behavior. The chromosome most likely to be involved in this disorder is chromosome
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) This 3-year-old girl is showing signs of rett’s disorder which is linked to the x chromosome. Rett’s disorder is characterized by loss of social skills after a period of typical functioning as well as hand wringing and breathing abnormalities
